_prev_prog_2.FR_Comments: OSHAS 18001 Safety Management Systems ISO Standard
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Leak detection at carbon canister systems, process valves and flanges. Contractor also completed inspection and maintenance of all rail lines to facility.
_prev_prog_2.Description:
The Geocycle prevention program covers both Processes  7.    PREVENTION PROGRAM LEVEL 2, SUBPART C
The Geocycle HWDF systems and feed to the Holcim cement kiln, related utility and safety systems are subject to the requirements of Prevention Program Level 2.  
Geocycle has developed and implemented seven elements required by Prevention Program Level 2:
?    Safety Information            68.42
?    Hazard Review            68.50
?    Operating Procedures            68.52
?    Training                68.54
?    Compliance Audits            68.58
?    Incident Investigation            68.60
?    Maintenance                68.56
7.1.    SAFETY INFORMATION    68.48
Geocycle compiled the safety information required under the RMP regulations as it assists in the understanding of the safety-related aspects of the equipment and processes, and the limitations placed on the operations and the adopted codes and standards.  First the bulk containers used for delivering the waste fuel containing the RMP compounds are DOT-specification containers and are required to be tested periodically for tightness and adequacy for carrying hazardous materials.  Documentation of the safety and design information on the typical process equipment, along with the corresponding design codes, is maintained in the plant?s Engineering and Maintenance Records.  The information contained on the Safety Information Sheet must be reviewed and updated on a periodic basis for completeness and accuracy.  The maximum intended inventory for each RMP Toxic Chemical is limited in the List of Chemicals in Table #1 and #2..  
7.2.    HAZARD REVIEW    68.50
The facility completed a hazard review of its RMP regulated process (HWDF facility operations) in January 28 and 29, 2008 for the Direct Burn Process and September 2006,and Management of Change Review February 6, 2007 for the Blend Tank Process (update to the initial PHA performed in June 2001 and December 1999).  The Process Hazard Analysis [PHA] used a structured ?what-if? technique, a systematic, multidisciplinary team oriented analytical approach.
The PHA identified:
7.2.1.    Hazards associated with the process and regulated chemicals
7.2.2.    Potential for equipment malfunctions or human errors that could cause a release
7.2.3.    Safeguards that control the hazards or prevent the malfunction or error
7.2.4.    Steps to detect or monitor releases
The PHA results have been documented and are retained on file at the facility.  Implementation of the PHA recommendations is ongoing and essentially a continuing process.  The Hazard Review shall be updated minimally every 5 years or with any process or equipment change that occurs that impacts the covered processes. 
7.3.    OPERATING PROCEDURES    68.52
Geocycle has written operating procedures that describe in detail what tasks a process operator must perform, set safe process operating parameters that must be maintained, and set safety precautions for operations and maintenance activities.  These procedures are the guide for employees on how to work safely, providing a readily accessible source of comprehensive information that can prevent or mitigate the effects of an accident, and providing workers and management with a standard against which to assess performance.
Geocycle must have written operating procedures for each of the following:
7.3.1.    Initial startup
7.3.2.    Normal operations
7.3.3.    Temporary operations
7.3.4.    Emergency shutdown
7.3.5.    Emergency operations
7.3.6.    Normal shutdown
7.3.7.    Startup following a normal or emergency shutdown or a major change
7.3.8.    Consequence of deviation and steps required to avoid or correct deviations and
7.3.9.    Equipment inspection
The operating procedures shall be updated any time there is a change in the process in a way that alters the steps needed to operate safely.  Examples of changes that may require an update to the operating procedures include the installation of new operating equipment, a change in the safety information for the regulated chemical or process equipment, as well as the identification of additional hazards during the updates to the facility hazard review.
7.4.    TRAINING    68.54
Under the RMP regulations in 40 CFR Part 68.54, all new workers and experienced workers must be trained in the Operating Procedures prior to starting working on an RMP covered process.  Training will also be given any time the procedures are revised as everyone must be trained in using the new procedures. At least once every three years, and more often if necessary, employees will be consulted by Geocycle to establish a refresher training regimen.  Refresher training shall be provided on the operating procedures even if they have not changed.  The training must cover all parts of the operating procedures, including information on the consequences of deviations and steps needed to address deviations. 
Under the provisions of 40 CFR ? 68.54?, the facility ?may use training conducted under Federal or state regulations or under industry specific standards or codes or training conducted by covered process equipment vendors to demonstrate compliance with this section to the extent that the training meets the requirements of this section?.  Under the prevailing federal RCRA regulations, all HWDF facility and cement plant employees associated with hazardous waste operations are trained within 6 months of hire.  The training includes the following:
24 Hours initial RCRA/MSHA hazardous waste operations and emergency training  
8 hours RCRA/MSHA annual refresher training
Classroom and on-the-job training is conducted, along with written examinations as required for certain safety clients.  All training logs and records are maintained on site.
7.5.    MAINTENANCE    68.56
Preventive maintenance, inspection, and testing of equipment are critical to safe operations.  Geocycle has prepared and implemented procedures for maintaining the mechanical integrity of process equipment, and trained applicable workers and contractors in the maintenance procedures, under 40 CFR 68.52. 
As required under 40 CFR ? 264/265, the facility has already implemented ?Procedures to Prevent Hazards? as an integral part of its hazardous waste management operations.  These written procedures meet or exceed the requirements for preventive maintenance, inspection and testing under the RMP regulations and are being incorporated by reference.  They provide a detailed list of the equipment to be tested and the inspection frequency.  The schedules already in practice are based on: 
7.5.1.    Regulatory Compliance Requirements
7.5.2.    Manufacturer?s Recommendations
7.5.3.    Industry Standards or Codes
7.5.4.    Good Engineering Practices
All employees associated with preventive maintenance, inspection and testing are trained in the procedures.
7.6.    COMPLIANCE AUDITS     68.58
Geocycle will review and audit the RMP Plan every three years, at a minimum, to ensure that the plan is implemented and documented adequately.  The audit program is designed to evaluate and measure the effectiveness of the Risk Management Program and ensure that the prevention program elements are up-to-date and appropriate for current operations.
The compliance audit will be conducted every 3 years by an individual (or team); knowledgeable of both the regulated processes as well as the RMP regulations [40 CFR Part 68].  The compliance audit will include a review of all elements of the RMP plan including:
7.6.1.    Safety Information
7.6.2.    Hazard Review
7.6.3.    Change in Regulated Process or Regulated Chemicals
7.6.4.    Records
Upon completion of the compliance audit, all findings shall be summarized in a written report.  Geocycle will promptly determine and document an appropriate response to each audit finding and further document all corrective actions taken to address any deficiencies.  Copies of the two most recent compliance audits and documentation of all corrective actions will be maintained at the facility.  A copy of the blank audit form used by South Carolina DHEC is included in Appendix 7.
7.7.    Incident Investigation    68.60
Geocycle will perform an investigation of each incident which has resulted in, or could have resulted in a catastrophic release of a regulated chemical.  A catastrophic release is one that presents an imminent and substantial endangerment to public health and the environment.
The following steps will be taken in performing an incident investigation:
7.7.1.    Initiate an investigation as promptly as possible, as but no later than 48 hours following the incident.
7.7.2.    Summarize the investigation in a report.  Incorporate all factors contributing to the incident including:  date of incident; date investigation began, a description of the incident; the factors that contributed to the incident; and any recommendations resulting from the investigation.
7.7.3.    Address the investigation findings and recommendations.  Resolutions and corrective actions shall be documented.
7.7.4.    The findings shall be reviewed with all affected personnel to prevent future occurrence of similar incidents
7.7.5.    Each investigation report is maintained for a minimum of five years.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.    EXECUTIVE SUMMARY, 68.155
The Holcim (US) Inc./Geocycle LLC (Geocycle) facility in Holly Hill, South Carolina manages  hazardous waste derived fuels  (HWDF) that are used to reduce fossil fuel and natural raw material consumption in the Holcim portland cement manufacturing facility.  Geocycle has prepared this plan and submitted a predictive RMP Plan to maintain future operational flexibility.  
1.1.    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION/EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES (A)
Geocycle?s prevention program complies with all applicable procedures of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) 40 CFR-68, Level 2 Prevention Program.
1.1.1.    Management System   (a) (1)
Geocycle has a management system that is lead by the Facility Manager, and supporting staff.  This is depicted in an organization chart.
1.1.2.    Prevention Program Level 2   (a) (2)
Geocycle maintains policies, procedures and systems as part of our prevention program.  It also includes all requirements for a RCRA hazardous waste facility.
1.2.    REGULATED SUBSTANCE HANDLED AT GEOCYCLE, HOLLY HILL, SC SITE   (B)
The Geocycle Plant employs 26 full-time employees engaged in HWDF plant 
1.2.1.    Site Description   (b) (1)
The site is owned by Holcim (US) and is managed and operated by Geocycle.  The site is located within the Holcim Cement Plant site 2175 Gardner Blvd, Holly Hill, Orangeburg County, SC
1.2.2.    Regulated Substance   (b) (2)
HWDFs include both flammable and toxic chemicals
1.2.2.1.    Process 1, Tank Farm/Blend Tank System, covers 41 Flammable and 12 toxic chemicals
1.2.2.2.    Process 2, Direct Burn System, includes nine toxic as well as each Process 1, flammable (41) and toxic (12) chemicals 
1.3.    WORST AND ALTERNATIVE CASE RELEASE SCENARIOS   (C)
Offsite consequence analyses were conducted which include two release scenarios for each covered HWDF Process.  All results are maintained on site and included in the RMP Submit program  
1.3.1.    Worst Case   (c) (1)
Atmospheric dispersion mod

eling for the worst case scenario was performed for each flammable and toxic chemical using the EPA?s RMP-COMP program.  
1.3.2.    Alternative Case   (c) (2)
The alternative release scenario involves a 100-gallon-per-minute leak in a tank, pump, pipe or associated storage and transfer equipment.  Modeling was performed using the EPA?s RMP COMP program based on a duration of 60 minutes, which is a conservative assumption.
1.4.    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE LEVEL 2 PREVENTION PROGRAM   (C)
The Geocycle accidental release prevention program is based on EPA?s RMP Level 2 prevention program.  Also Geocycle HWDF policies and procedures meets RCRA requirements for a permitted hazardous waste treatment, storage and disposal facility and MSHA safety standards.  
1.4.1.    General Accidental Release Prevention Program   (C) (1)
Plant-wide elements of the prevention program are used for all operations.  An overview of the generally written program?s elements is listed below:
1.4.1.1.    Process safety information for chemicals and equipment. 
1.4.1.2.    A hazards review policy and reports
1.4.1.3.    Operating procedures are developed and implemented 
1.4.1.4.    Training program is established in each area for subject employees and contactors.  
1.4.1.5.    Maintenance and preventive maintenance is conducted and documented
1.4.1.6.    Geocycle?s compliance audits policy is followed. Reports are on site.
1.4.1.7.    Incident investigations of accidents and near-misses are reported 
1.4.2.    HWDF-Specific Response Program   (c) (2)
1.4.2.1.    Chemical-specific prevention for the plant includes the policies and procedures listed above and those of the HWDF specific program.  
1.4.2.2.    Facility and equipment design meet recognized codes and good engineering standards as NFPA, etc.
1.5.    FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY (E)
The facility has no RMP recordable incidents in the past 5 years.  
1.6.    EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM   (F)
Emergency response procedures are contained in both the Plant Emergency Response Policy and Continge

ncy Plan (Emergency Response Plan, developed under RCRA requirements for a hazardous waste treatment storage and disposal facility).  Geocycle is a non-responding facility and the Emergency Response Program meets RMP 68.95 described in Section 7 of this plan.
1.7.    CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY   (G)
Changes to improve safety (recommended actions) were identified in the internal safety Hazards Analysis, tour, and audits in preparation to implement the RMP program.   These were addressed.  Geocycle continually reviews implemented operating procedures for potential safety improvements for all of its operations.
